ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about interesting concepts pertaining to law and society. As someone with some background in legal studies, this course was definitely a social science driven approach to legal topics that I had not experienced yet.
I developed knowledge about scholarship in the field of legal sociology.
i developed a strong understanding of fundamental concepts in legal sociology and a better grasp on how to research.
I learned about different approaches to political science research and gained a range of insights regarding the relationship between law and society from the readings.
How to read and analyze political theory literature and think about these concepts in real life settings

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Syllabus and readings were clearly meticulously planned. Prof. Lazarev was knowledgeable and engaging in class. 

Weakness was weak participation by some students in class.
The course did not have a clear purpose or design in terms of learning.

great course, i especially like how you can king of choose where to focus and i feel like it's optimized well around writing a really good and meaningful final.  however, I wish that the normal seminars were a little less summary focused and went a little deeper into both the readings individually and how they connected to each other.

Strengths are the readings (most of which are really interesting) and Professor Lazarev, who is really knowledgeable and approachable. Weaknesses are the student presentations, which can go on for a long time and could be more question-oriented to engage those not presenting.
The course was very intellectually challenging and helped foster in depth discussions during class. The readings were a bit dense though and much more difficult than any others. Ive encountered.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend to social science students who may want to gain some exposure to legal topics.

I would not reccomend this course to another student. The class was not well designed and it was not clear what the purpose of the class was. Moreover, it was a seminar that ran like a lecture and I don't feel this was at all conducive to learning.
i'd definitely recommend this course.  Prof. Lazarev is great and the subject is super interesting and useful.

Yes! The readings are really interesting and Professor Lazarev is really knowledgeable and approachable. I gained a new perspective on the law, which I would've have got from any other law-relate class at Yale. As long as you start the research project before Thanksgiving, the workload in manageable.

Yes--Professor Lazarev is first class in his ability to simplify tough concepts and trends within comparative legal studies while providing the class with ample resources to succeed. The first few seminars/readings are a little slower as the class begins by focusing on laying a methodological and conceptual foundation that is imperative to understanding and analyzing the following readings and legal frameworks. Once the foundation is laid, the class begins to explore the status of law in a comparative nature. From comparing social change, legal consciousness, colonialism, democracy, to authoritarianism, gender, conflict, and policing. Throughout the semester, the class was regularly engaging with the readings, each other, and current events. Personally, I found that the entire class enjoyed most, if not all, of the readings and material. Professor Lazarev is understanding yet particular about his standards for the work submitted. This has been one of the more rewarding seminars that I have taken and would strongly recommend any PLSC senior (or senior interested in LAW) to enroll in the seminar.
Yes, if you are interested in law or comparative politics I think you would find the course very engaging and intellectually stimulating.
